body_text.text: In this new world shrouded by the COVID-19 pandemic, lives are changing so rapidly it's impossible to 43 keep up. Each person is being called upon to do the best they can for the health and safety of 44 themselves, their families, and their communities. The JACI: In Practice team has been working hard to 45 gather resources for our readers. We hope to be a continuing source of information and support for 46 allergy/immunology clinicians in what seems like a desperate time of need.

BIBREF0.title: We are continuing to pursue other resources to help our clinician readers cope and practice during this 74 crisis. Please visit our website (www.jaci-inpractice.org) to take advantage of the newest resources and 75 view additional articles exploring other aspects of allergy/immunology care in these quite 76 unprecedented circumstances

BIBREF1.title: We recognize that many of you have been directly affected by COVID-19 and want to offer our heartfelt 79 sympathies to you. We also greatly appreciate those on the front lines of this World War V (for Virus

BIBREF8.title: COVID-19: Pandemic Contingency 99 Planning for the Allergy and Immunology Clinic

BIBREF9.title: Telemedicine in the Era of COVID-19

FIGREF0.text: time you read this Editorial we will have published online several articles related to the practice 49 of allergy/immunology during the COVID-19 pandemic. Two of those articles are included in this issue of 50 the Journal. 1,2 Marcus Shaker, Matt Greenhawt, and 19 other experts from around the United States 51 have provided a very extensive guide to contingency planning during this unprecedented crisis. 1 Their 52 comprehensive Special Article covers a wide range of relevant topics, including clinical background 53 regarding COVID-19 infections, prevention and control measures for healthcare workers, the 54 implications of emergency social distancing on ambulatory allergy/immunology care services, and 55 specific guidelines regarding each of the conditions allergist/immunologists commonly treat. This article 56 also details methods and policies on how to use telemedicine/telehealth services as a safer alternative 57 to in-person visits. In an excellent Editorial, Jay Portnoy and colleagues provide additional perspective, 58 guidance, and resources for incorporating various forms of telemedicine into allergy/immunology 59 practice during the current pandemic. 2 60 61 In addition to publishing articles, JACI: In Practice hosted a special edition of our Virtual Journal Club on 62 April 1, during which authors Marcus S. Shaker, Matthew Greenhawt, 1 and Jay Portnoy 2 discussed their 63 articles and answered questions from attendees. Benjamin Price, Vice Chair of the New 64 Allergist/Immunologist Assembly (NAIA) served as moderator. The webinar was recorded and the 65 recorded version is eligible for Continuing Medical Education (CME) credit.chat titled COVID-19: Pandemic Contingency Planning for Allergy and Immunology Clinic was 69 also held. On March 31 authors 1 David Stukus and Matthew Greenhawt answered clinicians' questions 70 on how to plan during this pandemic. You can view the tweets from this event at ADDLINKHERE 71 #JACIIPCOVID. Further Twitter chats are planned as new articles come online. 72
